title: 112_s1445
content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines terms such as "covered vehicle" as a motor vehicle under 26,000 pounds, rented without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles for rental purposes. It also defines terms like "defect" and "person" according to specific sections of the United States Code. The term "rental company" refers to a person in the business of renting or leasing 5 or more covered vehicles. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON RENTAL, LEASE, AND SALE OF DEFECTIVE CARS AND TRUCKS. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of covered vehicles with safety defects unless remedied prior to transaction. During a rental or lease period, if a rental company receives a notification of a safety defect in a covered vehicle, they must immediately contact the renter or lessee and any authorized driver. The rental company is considered to have received the notification 5 business days after it was mailed. The rental company must contact the renter or lessee and any authorized driver about a safety defect in a covered vehicle. They must offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the defect is fixed. This section will take effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce the provisions outlined in the Act. Violation of this Act will be treated as a violation of a rule under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. Penalties for violations will be in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission Act. Authority Preserved: This section does not limit the Commission's authority under other laws. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in a US district court for violations of the Act or its regulations to obtain injunctive relief. Additionally, the State attorney general must notify the Federal Trade Commission of any such action. The State attorney general must notify the Federal Trade Commission before initiating a civil action, providing a copy of the complaint. If immediate notice is not feasible, the State must notify upon instituting the action. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in the action upon receiving the required notice. The State attorney general must notify the Federal Trade Commission before initiating a civil action. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in the action, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. The section does not prevent the state attorney general from exercising their powers or proceeding in court based on alleged violations. No separate suit can be brought under this section. No separate suit can be brought under this section if the same alleged violation is the subject of a pending action by the Federal Trade Commission or the United States. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features. The report will include descriptions of buying practices, implications on consumer safety, and recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions. The report will include descriptions of buying practices, implications on consumer safety, and recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions to protect consumers. SEC. 8. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration report on sales of motor vehicles by rental companies with safety defects before recalls. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act on sales of covered vehicles by rental companies aware of safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act on sales of covered vehicles by rental companies in compliance with safety standards and notifications related to defects or non-compliance. The report must include specific elements as outlined. The Administrator must submit a report to Congress on the sales of covered vehicles by rental companies, including frequency, effects on consumers, and recommendations for legislative action. A follow-up report is required within 1 year of the initial submission. The Administrator must submit a report to Congress on the sales of covered vehicles by rental companies, including frequency, effects on consumers, and recommendations for legislative action. The report should include a description, analysis, discussion, and recommendations for the specified period, an analysis of differences between findings, and a discussion of the effects of the Act on vehicle sales. The Administrator must submit a report to Congress on the sales of covered vehicles by rental companies, including frequency, effects on consumers, and recommendations for legislative action. The report should include a description, analysis, discussion, and recommendations for the specified period, an analysis of differences between findings, and a discussion of the effects of this Act on the sales of covered vehicles.
